revisions.rev:
{{Infobox College Soccer Team |name = Virginia Cavaliers
men's soccer |logo = |current = 2011 Virginia Cavaliers men's soccer team |logo_size = 107px |university = University of Virginia |conference = Atlantic Coast Conference |conference_short = ACC |division = |founded=1941 |city = Charlottesville |stateabb = VA |state = Virginia |coach = [[George Gelnovatch]] |tenure = 16th |stadium = [[KlÃ¶ckner Stadium]] |capacity = 8,000 |nickname = Cavs, Hoos |color1 = Orange |color2 = Navy Blue |color3 = |fontcolor = FF7003 |hex1 = 0D3268 |hex2 = FF7003 |hex3 = | pattern_la1= |pattern_b1= _aachen1112A |pattern_ra1= | leftarm1=FFFFFF |body1=FFFFFF |rightarm1=FFFFFF |shorts1=0D3268 |socks1=FFFFFF | pattern_la2= |pattern_b2= _mhsc1112g1 |pattern_ra2= | leftarm2=FF7003 |body2=FF7003 |rightarm2=FF7003 |pattern_sh2 = _adidaswhite |shorts2=0D3268 |socks2=FF7003 |NCAAchampion = 1989, 1991, 1992, 1993, 1994, 2009 |NCAArunnerup =1997 |NCAAcollegecup =1983, 1989, 1991, 1992, 1993, 1994, 1995, 1997, 2006, 2009 |NCAAeliteeight = 1983, 1984, 1988, 1989, 1990, 1991, 1992, 1993, 1994, 1995, 1997, 1998, 1999, 2000, 2004, 2006, 2009 |NCAAsweetsixteen = |NCAAtourneys = 1969, 1979, 1981, 1982, 1983, 1984, 1985, 1986, 1987, 1988, 1989, 1990, 1991, 1992, 1993, 1994, 1995, 1996, 1997, 1998, 1999, 2000, 2001, 2002, 2003, 2004, 2005, 2006, 2007, 2008, 2009, 2010, 2011 |conference_tournament = 1988, 1991, 1992, 1993, 1994, 1995, 1997, 2003, 2004, 2009 |conference_season = 1979, 1984, 1986, 1987, 1988, 1989, 1990, 1991, 1992, 1995, 1996, 1998, 2000, 2001, 2005, 2010 }} The '''[[Virginia Cavaliers]] men's soccer team''' represent the [[University of Virginia]] in all NCAA Division I men's soccer competitions. The team is a member of the [[Atlantic Coast Conference]]. The team has grown an extensive reputation as having one of the most elite collegiate soccer programs in the United States, producing several future U.S. national team players. Notable examples include [[Claudio Reyna]] and [[John Harkes]]. Present [[Los Angeles Galaxy]] coach [[Bruce Arena]] coached the team and led them to five consecutive College Cup titles in the 1990s. == History == The University of Virginia first fielded a varsity men's soccer team in 1941 as an independent team. In their first season, the team posted a winless record, losing all nine of their matches. The team made their first appearance in the [[NCAA Men's Division I Soccer Championship]] in 1969, where they played their out-of-state rivals, the [[Maryland Terrapins men's soccer|Maryland Terrapins]]. The team was eliminated in the first round of the tournament following a 5â0 defeat. Ten years would pass before the Cavaliers would make their second tournament appearance, this time losing to the [[American Eagles]], 1â0 in the opening round. The team would make two more NCAA tournament appearances, in 1981 and 1982, before eventually progressing past the first round of the tournament. In the 1983 tournament, the Cavaliers defeated stateside opponents [[William & Mary Tribe men's soccer|William & Tribe]] by a 2â1 scoreline to advance into the quarterfinals. The tournament would culimnate with a quarterfinal victory over the [[San Francisco Dons#Men's Soccer|San Francisco Dons]] before bowing out in the semifinals to the eventual champions, the [[Indiana Hoosiers men's soccer|Indiana Hoosiers]]. During this period though, led under head coach [[Bruce Arena]], the Cavaliers developed a well-renowned reputation as being one of the most elite soccer programs in the country. Following their 1981 tournament appearance, the Cavaliers would qualify for the NCAA Men's Division I tournament every consecutive season to date, one of the longest streaks in NCAA history for any sport. Their apex came in the late 1980s to early 1990s, when the team won five national collegiate championships in the span of six years. Future [[United States men's national soccer team|U.S. men's national team]] stars such as [[John Harkes]] and [[Claudio Reyna]] were members of the championship team. The Cavaliers would win the 1989, 1991, 1992, 1993 and 1994 editions of the tournament. Subsequent to their dynasty run, the [[United States Soccer Federation]], in the promise of hosting the [[1994 FIFA World Cup]] instituted the creation of a new top tier professional soccer league, later to be named [[Major League Soccer]]. Upon the creation of the league, one of the league's clubs, [[D.C. United]] hired Arena as their full time head coach, where he led them to three [[MLS Cup]] titles, two [[MLS Supporters' Shield]]s and a [[CONCACAF Champions League|CONCACAF]] title. The departure of Arena saw a new replacement fill managerial duties in 1996. Arena would be replaced by longtime assistant, [[George Gelnovatch]], whom still today coaches the team. Initially under the helm of Gelnovatch, the Cavaliers were still a fairly successful team in the [[Atlantic Coast Conference]] and in the NCAA tournaments, although their success in the latter half of the 1990s and early 2000s could not replicate the same success in the late 1980s and early 1990s. During Gelnovatch's early years, the team's best finish was making the finals of the 1997 NCAA Men's Soccer championship, but to only lose 2â0 to the [[UCLA Bruins#Soccer|UCLA Bruins]]. After a period of decline in the early 2000s, the team had a successful campaign in 2009, reaching the final for the first time since 1997. Playing against the recently upstart [[Akron Zips men's soccer|Akron Zips]], the Cavaliers were able to defeat the Zips in a penalty kick shootout to claim their sixth NCAA title, and their first national championship since the Arena years. Since the Cavaliers won the 2009 NCAA Championship, they have been eliminated in the first round of the 2010 and 2011 editions of the tournament, losing to [[Colonial Athletic Association|CAA]] opponents on both occasions; Old Dominion and Delaware, respectively. == Stadium == {{main|KlÃ¶ckner Stadium}} One of the earliest [[soccer-specific stadium]]s in college soccer, the Virginia Cavaliers men's soccer team plays their home matches at the 8,000-seater [[KlÃ¶ckner Stadium]]. Since its opening in 1997, the Cavaliers have enjoyed some of the highest reported attendance figures in American college soccer. The stadium has 3,600 grandstand seats along with an addition 3,400 grass seats. It is shared with the [[Virginia Cavaliers women's soccer|women's soccer]] team, as well as the [[Virginia Cavaliers men's lacrosse|men's]] and [[Virginia Cavaliers women's lacrosse|women's lacrosse]] teams.{{cite web|title=KlÃ¶ckner Stadium and Team Locker Rooms|url=http://www.virginiasports.com/ViewArticle.dbml?&DB_OEM_ID=17800&KEY=&ATCLID=1134413|publisher=University of Virginia|accessdate=August 19, 2011}} == Fans == === Rivalries === ;Maryland Best known for their [[MarylandâVirginia football rivalry|college football rivalry]] many cite the rivaly between the Cavaliers and the [[Maryland Terrapins men's soccer|Maryland Terrapins]] as one of the most bitter rivalries in college soccer.{{cite web|title=Virginia, Maryland Renew Men's Soccer Rivalry This Weekend|url=http://virginiasports.cstv.com/sports/m-soccer/spec-rel/091298aaa.html|work=University of Virginia|publisher=CBSSports.com|accessdate=August 19, 2011|date=September 12, 1998}}{{cite web|title=The 5 Greatest Rivalries in College Soccer|url=http://firstpointusa.com/news/the-5-greatest-rivalries-in-college-soccer/|work=Collegesoccernews.com|publisher=First Point USA|accessdate=August 19, 2011}} The two sides have long been heavyweights in the ACC and are among the colleges with the most NCAA Division I championships in the sport.{{cite news|last=Goff|first=Steven|title=Maryland, Virginia men's soccer meet again, this time in NCAA tournament|url=http://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2009/12/03/AR2009120304289.html|accessdate=August 19, 2011|newspaper=The Washington Post|date=December 4, 2009}} Throughout the 1970s, the rivalry was heavily dominated by Maryland only for the fortunes to be reversed in the 1990s. Additionally, the two sides have clashed six times against one another in the ACC championship. ;Virginia Tech {{main|Virginia â Virginia Tech rivalry}} As interconference members, and having a longstanding rivalry, another one of the top rivals of the Virginia Cavaliers is the [[Virginia Tech Hokies men's soccer|Virginia Tech Hokies]]. The series between the two has [[Virginia â Virginia Tech rivalry#All-time and ACC series results|been heavily dominated]] by the Cavaliers, who boast a 35â4â1 record against the Hokies.{{cite web|url=http://www.virginiasports.com/pdf5/88829.pdf|title=#4 VIRGINIA vs. #16 VIRGINIA TECH|format=PDF}} However, in ACC play, the Cavaliers only better the Hokies by a 4â2â1. ;Other rivalries With the success of [[Colonial Athletic Association]] teams in men's collegiate soccer, as well as their geographic proximity, there has been reported rivalries between the Cavaliers and the [[Old Dominion Monarchs men's soccer|Old Dominion Monarchs]], the [[VCU Rams men's soccer|Virginia Commonwealth Rams]]{{cite web|title=A late goal gives Virginia the victory over VCU|url=http://www.virginiasportstv.com/menssoccer/B5m|publisher=VirginiaSportsTV.com|accessdate=August 19, 2011|date=October 5, 2009}} and the [[William & Mary Tribe men's soccer|William & Mary Tribe]]. The Cavaliers have met these opponents in numerous out of conference games, and in the NCAA tournament where they have even been defeated by Old Dominion. == Roster == === 2011â12 squad === ''As of July 20, 2011''{{cite web |title=Men's Soccer - 2011 Roster |url=http://www.virginiasports.com/SportSelect.dbml?DB_OEM_ID=17800&SPID=10604&SPSID=88787 |publisher=University of Virginia |accessdate=2011-08-14}} {{Football squad start}} {{Football squad player|no=0|pos=GK|nat=THA|name=Matt Miscione}} {{Football squad player|no=1|pos=GK|nat=ESP|name=Spencer LaCivita}} {{Football squad player|no=2|pos=DF|nat=USA|name=Kevin McBride}} {{Football squad player|no=3|pos=DF|nat=USA|name=Matt Brown}} {{Football squad player|no=4|pos=DF|nat=USA|name=Grant Silvester}} {{Football squad player|no=5|pos=FW|nat=BRA|name=Bryan Lima}} {{Football squad player|no=6|pos=DF|nat=MON|name=Greg Monaco}} {{Football squad player|no=7|pos=MF|nat=MEX|name=Felipe Libreros}} {{Football squad player|no=8|pos=FW|nat=USA|name=Chris Somerville}} {{Football squad player|no=9|pos=FW|nat=USA|name=Brian Ownby}} {{Football squad player|no=10|pos=FW|nat=USA|name=Will Bates}} {{Football squad player|no=11|pos=MF|nat=USA|name=Eric Bird}} {{Football squad player|no=12|pos=MF|nat=CIV|name=Ahkeel Rodney}} {{Football squad player|no=13|pos=MF|nat=CUB|name=Conner Rezende}} {{Football squad player|no=15|pos=DF|nat=GER|name=Mike Volk}} {{Football squad mid}} {{Football squad player|no=16|pos=DF|nat=IRL|name=Sean Hiller}} {{Football squad player|no=17|pos=DF|nat=USA|name=Hunter Jumper}} {{Football squad end}} == Team management == ;Coaching Staff {{Fb cs header}} {{Fb cs staff |bg= |p=Head Coach |s={{Flagicon|USA}} [[George Gelnovatch]]}} {{Fb cs staff |bg=y |p=Associate Head Coach |s={{Flagicon|USA}} [[Matt Chulis]]}} {{Fb cs staff |bg= |p=Asst.
